node.title: Peacock - No module named 'PyQt5' Error
node.bodyText:
I have downloaded MOOSE and am working on my first example simulations, but visualizing them with Peacock only leads to the following error:
(base) scholar2bee@MSI:~$ conda activate peacock
(peacock) scholar2bee@MSI:~$ docker run -it -v projects:/projects idaholab/moose-dev:latest
bash-4.4# cd /projects/babbler/problems
bash-4.4# /projects/moose/python/peacock/peacock -r pressure_diffusion_out.e
Traceback (most recent call last):
 File "/projects/moose/python/peacock/peacock", line 36, in <module>
   run_peacock()
 File "/projects/moose/python/peacock/peacock", line 28, in run_peacock
   sys.exit(main(sys.argv))
 File "/projects/moose/python/peacock/peacock", line 12, in main
   from peacock.CheckRequirements import has_requirements
 File "/projects/moose/python/peacock/__init__.py", line 11, in <module>
   from . import base
 File "/projects/moose/python/peacock/base/__init__.py", line 10, in <module>
   from .MooseWidget import MooseWidget
 File "/projects/moose/python/peacock/base/MooseWidget.py", line 10, in <module>
   from PyQt5 import QtCore
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'PyQt5'
I am not sure how to move forward without being able to visualize the simulations in Peacock. What is the best way to fix this?

As soon as you executed docker, you exited the environment capable of running Peacock.
I don't think Docker is capable of looping back out of it (its a Container), to display/connect to your host systems Graphics API. Er... it may be possible, but I don't know the steps you'll need to take in order to do so.
If you want to view your simulation results, I suggest using Paraview. Basically you would use Docker to run the simulation, and then on the host machine open the result in Paraview.
I converted this to a discussion, as this is not a bug of MOOSE.

node.title: regarding capillary pressure: the van genuchten model
node.bodyText:
Hello,
this is an outsourced discussion from #26788:
A simulation of an unsaturated soil with a heatsource is done to fit experimental data. While the temperatures are fitting very nicely, the capillary pressure is still a bite of a riddle.
In the porous flow module,  the van genuchten function for "capillary pressure" is used, originating from the equation for saturation as a function of the pressure head - meaning that the capillary pressure would be the same as the matric potential?
The results of the experiment are given as matric potential (which would be the capillary pressure according to this), however the measured potential is way more sensitive than the one from the simulation (see image below).

The only way I could think of making the capillary pressure more sensivity would be, if the curve jump at a certain saturation, so that the capillary pressure could react fast and strong to small changes in saturation at thie specified range. This would not be possible with the relatively simple sigmoidal VG formulation though.
A suggestion for a solution to this problem was made by  Durner (1994, https://doi.org/10.1029/93WR02676), extending the function to account for multimodal poresize distribution, maybe this could be implemented?
Cheers
@cpgr

I did some simple calculations and so far I don't think, that the model by Durner is of much help in this case (although it might still be an interesting addition to the module).
I would still appreciate some input on how to make the model more sensitive to changes in saturation, that is if there is an actual logical on easy approach.

node.title: Outputing the residual as an AuxVariable?
node.bodyText:
Hi all.
So we are having problem with convergence from our hydro simulation,
just wondering, is it possible to output the residual as an auxVariable?
That way we could find "where" the problem is (check via Paraview), whether it appears to be a spatially local area, or overall bad residuals

Kind regards,
Traiwit

Hello, you can use DebugResidualAux for this:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/DebugResidualAux.html
Best regards,
Kavan
this is what we need, thank you @Kavan-Khaledi !

Our Conda packages and Homebrew do not mix. Basically you were using two different MPI wrappers (one supplied by Brew, the other by Conda). You can only make one available within your environment at any one point in time.
The errors you are seeing are related to you using our Conda packages built with MPICH supplied by Conda, and then using MPICH supplied by Homebrew when you ran make in moose/test. In order to remedy the conflict, you need to start over (clean your partially built copy of MOOSE).
cd /Users/liumiao/projects/moose
git clean -xfd
git submodule foreach --recursive git clean -xfd
Next, you'll need to build your own copy of PETSc, libMesh, and WASP manually (the libraries previously being supplied by Conda) using your Homebrew MPI stack . Assuming everything is clean at this point, and your Homebrew stack is the only stack present:

Verify Compilers are set

echo $CC $CXX $FC
mpicc mpicxx mpif90
If the above echo results are different, you need to set them according:
export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx FC=mpif90 F90=mpif90 F77=mpif77
Note: If you needed to run the above export, then this needs to be done each time you start a new terminal window and wish to use MOOSE.

Verify MPI wrappers are available:

which $CC $CXX $FC $F77
The above should return paths to your MPI wrappers. If you don't see 4 paths being returned, that means one is missing, and you need to install it using Brew.

If the above commands are good, you can proceed to building the PETSc, libMesh, and WASP dependencies:

export MOOSE_JOBS=6   # This is how many cores your machine has
export METHODS=opt    # This tells libMesh to only build the optimized method (speed things up)
cd /Users/liumiao/projects/moose/scripts
./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
./update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh
Note: building each of these takes time. If your machine has 6 cores, I would estimate about 30 minutes to complete all three.

Build MOOSE. If none of the above failed, we can now build MOOSE:

cd /Users/liumiao/projects/moose/test
make -j $MOOSE_JOBS
If there were any errors during any of the above, please run the ./diagnostics.sh script again in moose/scripts and post the results! Thanks!

node.title: Newer version of moose fails to execute on more than a specific number of nodes on a HPC cluster
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I use a moose based app for my simulations on a linux cluster. Usually on older moose releases, I was capable of running my simulations on 24 nodes using MPI tasks and threads (e.g SLURM setup : --nodes=24 --cpus-per-task=7 --ntasks-per-node=4). But now I have to use the newer moose release (post Oct 2022 releases) and now I can't use more than 8 nodes. I have a mesh of around 8 million elements and my executable link looks like the following: mpiexec   -n 96 mooseapp-opt --distributed-mesh -i  INPUT.i  --n-threads=7
Keep in mind that the mesh did not change at all and no errors are received when running tests. Also, the main reason why I used to use threading before is because it allowed me to use many nodes in moose older releases. Now however, it doesn't matter if I use threads or not because in both ways I will only be able to run on up to 8 nodes only. Could someone help me, please?

Hello
Can you please paste the actual error you are hitting? MOOSE should still work with any number of nodes
Guillaume
Unfortunately, the log file shows no error when the job is running. It will just not be executed and will stay blank until the time limit is reached.

Did you rule out a problem with your job scheduler?
Did you try running a simple command instead of moose
Is there maybe a .err file created which has the errors?

Yes, I ran a simple command and it seems it is not a problem with the scheduler or with mpi.
There are no .err file available but the output log returns nothing with the running moose job.
The input files, including the job submission file, are all the same before and after updating moose. The only thing that changed was the moose release.
and moose works with less processes? you still have successful runs with 4  nodes?
Yes. It works with 8 or less nodes.

Without a log we can only guess what s happening.
I'd say try a different timpi synch algorthim (use --help on the app to see what I m talking about)
then rebuild with a different MPI if that doesnt work

node.title: Setting a BC constant value as a function of time
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I have written a coupledNeumannBC code, part of which goes as follows:
params.addParam<Real>("temperatureE", 273.0, "environment temperature");
_temperatureE(getParam<Real>("temperatureE")),
return _test[_i][_qp] * _lambdaE * (_coupledTemperature_val[_qp] - _temperatureE);

_lambdaE is a constant,
_temperatureE is also a constant (environment temperature)
Now, I want _temperatureE to be a function of time (Something like a multi-line from data I have). I know how to do it with FunctionDirichletBC or similar. But I am not sure how to do it with this particular code.
Is there a built-in BC of MOOSE that has a similar function? or a type of function, which I can feed into the _temperatureE from the input file?
This is the input file part I use with this BC:
[topT]
    type = TKEnvTempCoupledNeumannBC
    variable = temperature
    lambdaE = 10
    temperatureE = 268.15
    temperature = temperature
    boundary = top
  []

I would appreciate your help.

No the attribute must have a different name for BCs
it's not
_current_qp[_qp]))

look at other BCs maybe
for nodal BCs it s *_current_node

Yes! You're right. It seems to be _q_point[_qp]
I found it in FunctionPenaltyDirichletBC
return _test[_i][_qp] * _lambdaE * (_coupledTemperature_val[_qp] - _temperatureE.value(_t, _q_point[_qp]));
It compiles. Does it seem right?
seems good to me
Thank you Guillaume for the help. I appreciate it.

node.title: Build and Test MOOSE Errors on Linux Ubuntu 22.04 Machine
node.bodyText:
I've previously been using MOOSE last week and earlier this week; however, my Linux laptop had to be re-imaged/wiped yesterday. I've just re-installed Anaconda and also I'm re-going through the MOOSE installation steps. I've cloned MOOSE successfully using the following:
